posts.cooked:
For quite a few days now, there is a new app available in the App Store, called “Session”.
I installed it, tried it out for a few minutes, and deleted it again.

As developer, the name “The Loki project” is given, and I think it is simple a Signal fork, which has some modifications. One of them being, that no phone number is asked for, another one, that it is not centralized anymore.

Anyone has more information on that?

link_counts.title: List of unofficial forks and patches
Clones of Signal in app stores and elsewhere

posts.cooked:
Well, it looks more interesting than Signal does, I can at least say that. Even the web-site is branded. I kinda like those dark-green accent on the branding. Matrix-like style. Gives it personality.

Above that, it is a fork of Signal:

GitHub

GitHub - oxen-io/session-ios: A private messenger for iOS.

A private messenger for iOS. Contribute to oxen-io/session-ios development by creating an account on GitHub.

They did not removed the Signal name from the directory structure and has

License

Copyright 2011 Whisper Systems
Copyright 2013-2017 Open Whisper Systems
Copyright 2019-2020 The Loki Project

It seems the code was not audited but they are in the process of arranging a full third-party code audit.

Session

Frequently Asked Questions - Session Private Messenger

Session's FAQ. Find answers to some of the most frequently asked questions about Session — info on the team, the tech, and the technicalities.

What is the Loki Project?
The Loki Project is the team behind Session. The Loki Project is supported by the not-for-profit Loki Foundation. Loki provides users with tools to interact online in an anonymous, decentralised, secure and private way. Loki builds and maintains the Loki privacy suite, comprised of a private transaction system, the $LOKI cryptocurrency, and a decentralised network of user-operated service nodes. Session uses this decentralised network to power its proxy routing system — and the onion requests system that will be replacing proxy routing.

I’m not sure I understand this correctly, but they work over a TOR network?

What is an onion routing network?

An onion routing network is a network of nodes over which users can send anonymous encrypted messages. Onion networks encrypt messages with multiple layers of encryption, then send them through a number of nodes. Each node ‘unwraps’ (decrypts) a layer of encryption, meaning that no single node ever knows both the destination and origin of the message. Session uses onion routing to ensure that a server which receives a message never knows the IP address of the sender.

Session’s onion routing system, known as onion requests , uses the Loki Project’s network of Loki Service Nodes, which also power the $LOKI cryptocurrency. Check out Loki.network for more information on the tech behind Session’s onion routing.

posts.cooked:
I am starting to warm up to this app. I made a small reasearch about these guys, they seem legit. It definitely looks much better and I managed to convince with no hassle two of my friends to try it out. And what do you know, we enjoyed it. It is actually really cool to chat on this app.

I know this, but still amaze me how important a comfortable and well thought UI really is. Especially when you come after two years of Siberia experience with original Signal app.

posts.name: willemk
posts.cooked: Sending messages is quit slow.

We didn’t experience that with the iOS version of the app and really strong Internet connection. But I can suspect that latency can arise from the fact they use the same routing strategy as the TOR network, passing the message through their network multiple times while encrypting it in transit.

posts.name: link ✦
posts.cooked:
anon17534525:

they use the same routing strategy as the TOR network, passing the message through their network multiple times while encrypting it in transit.

At this point, they don’t do that, as you’ll see below.

anon17534525:

I am starting to warm up to this app. I made a small reasearch about these guys, they seem legit. It definitely looks much better

But a lot of important features aren’t implemented yet, which they claim to have implemented (on the front page).

PSA

(from the whitepaper)
aka Let me end your Session

8 Addendum

This paper does not describe Session as it exists in its initial release some of the features described
in this paper will still need additional work before being deployed to the live Session application.
The most significant deviations from this paper and the Session application as of February 11th,
2020 are mentioned below:

  • Onion requests are not yet implemented in the initial release, and are replaced with Service
    Node proxy routing, which provides only a single hop, instead of the three hops which will
    be provided by onion requests.
  • In the initial release, proxy routing applies when communicating with Service Nodes and Loki
    File servers, but not Loki open group servers.
  • The proof of work difficulty threshold is controlled centrally, so that it can be manually raised
    if Service Nodes are being spammed.
  • Mappings between devices for multi-device are stored encrypted on the Loki File server instead
    of being communicated when adding a friend or joining an open group.
  • Some client-side protections, including duress codes, remote deletion, and backup and restore,
    are not yet implemented.
  • Service Node testing related to Session functionality is implemented and running, but not yet
    enforced.
  • Closed groups in the initial version of Session are implemented using the naive pairwise
    channel approach, and capped to a maximum of 10 users.

Haha, I saved the whitepaper so I can grasp through it when I get home today. You got ahead of me.

What I am curious is how they managed the Sync Across Devices part. I did not had time to play to much with the settings, but that sounds to me as some way of… storing state somewhere…

Hello,
Permission and trackers are ok. But I’m still thinking about all loki monero infrastructure. If that New fork of monero is convertible in others currencies could be scam, we have to be always in doubt when we here words like snake oil blockchain…bla bla.
I think the best part is not hidden identity ( impossible on stock android), but swarm nodes instead of Amazon servers. As you can read in white papers is " quite complicated " to achieve a “federated server”. And remember: no voip !

anon17534525:

as the TOR network,

but it’s not the real Tor: maybe it was as the late Ricochet worked. From what I understand Loki is a proprietary infrastructure anyway or am I wrong?

anon17534525:

Well, it looks more interesting than Signal does, I can at least say that. Even the web-site is branded. I kinda like those dark-green accent on the branding. Matrix-like style. Gives it personality.

I stopped testing Session after a short while, because of two reasons.

→ I think the user interface is at a point, at which Signal has been many years ago. Many options, which should be normal, haven’t been added yet. So, just to give one example, depending on the font size of the OS, the font size in Session should increase; as it does using WhatsApp or Signal. There is still much work to do. (this is not my main reason, though)

→ While I find the idea of an anonymous messenger interesting (not sure, if I really need it), I stopped testing it, right after I saw, that the project is localized in Australia.
After the Australian government made this completely stupid Assistance and Access bill, I refuse to use any software made in Australia. A (democratic) country, which is striving for such stupid legislation, does not deserve to export any software, may it be open-source or not. It should be thrown back into the stone age by users around the world, so that the average Australian citizen understands, that this government harms the future of the entire country.

posts.name: Harold Finch
posts.cooked:
hello,
Signal is made in USA, so I suppose Country is not a real difference…5 eyes.

Australia does not appear to be an impediment to a security and anonymity service like Session; as mentioned above, the USA itself has bad laws for such services.

And as for onion routing, it is done by the “Loki Network” project itself and not by Tor, as some have asked.

Reading the whitepapper, Session will in the future be a significant competitor to Signal: It will have anonymity, decentralized servers, local database encryption and much more.
